docs.lead_paragraph: One of the biggest surprises of this campaign year has been former Senator Bill Bradley's ability to be competitive with the Vice President in the campaign cash sweepstakes. Mr. Bradley has raised nearly $20 million this year and has more cash in the bank than Vice President Al Gore. But Mr. Bradley's fund-raising prowess should come as no surprise, despite his claim to be running as an insurgent candidate who espouses an overhaul of campaign finance.

headline.main: Bradley Relies On Wall Street To Raise Funds

docs.abstract: Bill Bradley has raised nearly $20 million this year in his quest for Democratic Presidential nomination, and much of it comes from Wall Street; he espouses overhaul of campaign finance and he has forsworn donations from political action committees, but his top fund-raisers are banking powerhouses, each of whom has enlisted dozens of bankers and traders from their firms, as well as wealthy friends and relatives, as $1,000 contributors; even Bradley's opponents cannot point to anything specific in his Senate career that would account for Wall Street's loyalty and generosity; his fund-raising network extends beyond Wall Street, to his contacts from 10 years as player with New York Knicks, to recruit top sports stars as fund-raising draws; he used year as visiting lecturer at Stanford to nurture relationships with Silicon Valley lawyers and venture capitalists, and they are raising money for him as well; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Unions See Fertile Fields at Lower End of High Tech'' (Grass-Roots Business, Sept. 26), which focused on the disadvantages of temporary employment in the technology industry:
docs.abstract: American Staffing Assn executive vice president Richard Wahlquist letter holds September 26 article on union interest in temporary workers at lower end of high technology industry is narrow and one-sided; holds staffing companies offer flexibility to employees and companies (S)g
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Unions See Fertile Fields at Lower End of High Tech'' (Grass-Roots Business, Sept. 26), which focused on the disadvantages of temporary employment in the technology industry:

docs.lead_paragraph: Next week Congress will debate legislation that would make it far more difficult for doctors everywhere to prescribe pain medication for the terminally ill. This proposal, introduced in the House by Henry Hyde, Republican of Illinois, and in the Senate by Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, intends to overturn Oregon's law on physician-assisted suicide, and it is an affront to anyone who favors compassionate care of patients at the end of life. The bill would give the Drug Enforcement Administration the power to determine whether a controlled substance has been prescribed for a legitimate medical purpose. As a result, law enforcement officials who have no expertise in health care would be creating and enforcing rules that would allow them to second-guess doctors across the country. Further, the legislation would specifically ban the use of drugs like morphine for physician-assisted suicide, effectively overturning Oregon's law.
docs.abstract: Sen Ron Wyden Op-ed article scores legislation in Congress that would make it far more difficult for doctors everywhere to prescribe pain medication for terminally ill (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first televised debate of the 2000 Presidential campaign, five Republican candidates last night excoriated President Clinton for his stewardship of foreign policy and virtually ignored the front-runner who did not take part, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. The candidates, appearing at the University of New Hampshire in Durham, needled one another on health care, abortion and relations with China. But there were no raised voices in the hourlong session as the contenders, sitting casually in a semicircle, offered mostly like-minded prescriptions on education, taxes, trade and moral values.
docs.abstract: Five Republican candidates meet at University of New Hampshire, Durham, for first televised debate of 2000 Presidential campaign; they excoriate Pres Clinton for his stewardship of foreign policy and virtually ignore front-runner who does not take part, Gov George W Bush; photo of Sen John McCain, Gary L Bauer, Sen Orrin G Hatch, Steve Forbes and Alan Keyes (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: During the careers of every living executive in the finance industry, bankers have made loans, brokers have sold stocks, insurers have underwritten policies to protect against disasters, and, with exceptions that sometimes made headlines, they rarely trespassed on one another's turf. This gentlemanly division of labor was intended to make sure that a catastrophic failure in one part of the finance industry did not invade every other part -- or, more precisely, that a stock market crash would not undermine the entire financial system as it did in 1929. It worked, and it has more or less endured: Even today, after a decade that has witnessed extensive consolidation and diversification in finance, it is not inaccurate to think of Chase Manhattan as a lender, Merrill Lynch as a broker, and Prudential as an insurer, though they all do other things as well.

headline.main: Financial Services Industry Faces a New World
headline.kicker: A NEW FINANCIAL ERA: THE IMPACT

docs.abstract: Financial services industry is about to undergo major overhaul as Congress deregulates banking, securities and insurance industries; shares in those three industries soar on merger speculation; biggest winners are life insurance companies, which some see as prime targets of banks hoping to offer insurance to their customers; investors see banks and brokerage firms as effectively in play as well, though industry executives say that change might come slower; consumers stand to gain from convenience of finding every financial product in one place, but consumer groups have already begun to raise red flags about privacy (M)
docs.snippet: During the careers of every living executive in the finance industry, bankers have made loans, brokers have sold stocks, insurers have underwritten policies to protect against disasters, and, with exceptions that sometimes made headlines, they rarely...

docs.lead_paragraph: Agreement to Overhaul Nation's Financial System The Clinton Administration and top Republican lawmakers agreed to overhaul the nation's financial system, repealing Depression-era laws that have restricted the banking, securities and insurance industries from expanding into one another's businesses.
docs.snippet: Agreement to Overhaul Nation's Financial System  The Clinton Administration and top Republican lawmakers agreed to overhaul the nation's financial system, repealing Depression-era laws that have restricted the banking, securities and insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ed Yingling, the chief lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, was weary this evening as he reflected on the agreement to overhaul the nation's financial system and the many years of lobbying behind it. ''I don't know; I can't quantify it,'' he said. ''But if I had to guess, I would say it's probably the most heavily lobbied, most expensive issue'' to come before Congress in a generation.

headline.main: Surveying the Results, 20 Years and Millions of Dollars Later
headline.kicker: A NEW FINANCIAL ERA: THE LOBBYING

docs.abstract: Banking deregulation has been vigorously lobbied and debated for 20 years by three of nation's wealthiest industries: banking, insurance and securities; Center for Responsive Politics says in 1997 and 1998 alone, these three industries gave $58 million to Federal political candidates; they donated $87 million in so-called soft money to political parties, and they reported spending $163 million in additional lobbying expenses; donations to some key legislators by three industries over years discussed; lobbying efforts of Senate Banking Committee members Sen Charles E Schumer, who supported deregulation, and Sen Phil Gramm, who opposed it, discussed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Describing poverty as a ''slow motion national disaster,'' former Senator Bill Bradley called yesterday for reducing the number of poor children by half over the coming decade by raising the minimum wage, increasing spending on child care programs and providing an array of tax benefits to poor parents who work. Evoking the Depression and the race to the Moon as challenges the nation had overcome through ingenuity and strong will, Mr. Bradley, who is challenging Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said it was morally unacceptable for a prosperous America to allow 1 in 5 of its children to live in dire need.

headline.main: Bradley Challenges Nation To Eliminate Child Poverty
